19921123.review:
Total Annihilation is a ridiculously fun and addictive RTS game that was developed in 1997 by a little company called Cavedog. For an almost 20-year-old game, it's amazing how fun this game is to still play. 

The user interface is very user-friendly, and the game itself is simple to learn. Despite the ease of being able to get into the game and just start playing, there is a wide variety of units that allow an incredible level of complex creativity in terms of strategy. Total Annihilation is like eating candy without the calories: it gives you a cool robot army, huge explosions, and probably one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard composed for a game.

Total Annihilation is also very mod-friendly and customizable. 

Despite being a great game, there are some pitfalls: Getting a multiplayer game can be tricky if you have no idea what you're doing. You will need to connect to the ip address of the host, which most modern games do for you automatically. Additionally, there is a unit cap of 250 (which includes buildings) that you *can* increase, but you have to manually edit the totala.ini file. This can be a pain in the butt for the computer-challenged, but isn't difficult to actually do. 

The main complaint I hear about this game is the pathfinding. And I agree. Sometimes your units will do what seem to be nonsensical things, like trying to drive up a wall instead of going around it. Very large armies also have difficulty moving around, and the units tend to get stuck on each other. Naval units are the best example of this, where they will grind against each other trying to find their way to a destination. There ARE pathfinding patches out there that will significantly help with these difficulties, though.

Overall, this is a great game. I highly recommend it for pretty much anyone ever.

The following is very easy for me to say and not at all biased.  Honest!

Total Annihilation.  A mandatory experience for any accomplished RTS enthusiast (seriously).  A Mega-tactical WTF, and absolutely way ahead of its time.  It recreated a whole new standard and ushered a new era of hardcore RTS gaming.  It maintains that standard to this day and can hold its head high.  The game has aged with grace so extremely well and I am proud and priveledged to have played it.  [b]Well worth it.[/b]  I'm sure many will agree here:  you MUST play this game.

19887518.review:
So, cool .... seit Win7 bei mir sein zuhause hat musste ich immer noch XP extra auf dem Rechner haben um dieses absolute Kult-Game noch spielen zu können. Alle versuche es in einer Virtuellen Maschine zu Starten waren vergebens, wenn man mit der "Core-Offensive" und "Battle Tactic" (hier mit enthalten) spielen wollte. Es fehlte in der Virtuellen Maschine wie unter Win7 einfach die 16bit Unterstützung zur Installation der Add-Ons.
Dank Steam ist diese Zeit nun vorbei und man kann das Game wieder richtig und in vollen zügen genießen.

Auch wer kein gutes Englisch kann, aber die Deutsche Version von damals gespielt hat, wird sich ohne probleme im Game zurecht finden.
Und noch zwei gute Nachrichten: 
- die Befehlskonsole nimmt auch hier die Cheats von füher an (so kann man zum Beispiel seinen Comander zum Singen bekommen ;) auch wenn er immer nur das selbe vorsich hin dudelt)
- sowie der Unit-Patch auch ausführbar ist.
Wer also diese Dinge noch sein "eigen" nennen kann, hat wieder soviel Spaß wie früher.

Kurz und knapp zum Spiel: 
Es geht um den Kamp zweier fortschritlichen und mechanischen Völker die sich seit langen bekämpfen. Du schlüpfst als Commander in einer der Rollen und musst dich zu Lande, Luft und Wasser (je nach Karten Wahl) mit knappen Recourcen gegen deinen Gegner behaupten und Ihn vernichten. Hier ist planerisches Geschick für die Gebäude und vermehrung der Recourcen genauso gefragt wie eine gute Taktik um den Gegner in die Knie zu zwingen.
Ihr könnt dabei die Seite auf der Ihr Kämpfen wollt frei wählen. Auf diese Art viele Missionen (über die man das Game auch kennenlernt) meistern oder im Freien Spiel mit bis zu drei KI Gegnern kämpfen. Das Spiel bietet auch hier die Multi-Player Unterstützung (habe ich noch nicht getestet), so könnt Ihr auch gegen reale Gegner antreten oder z.B. zu zweit gegen die KI antretten. Drei Schwierigkeitsstufen sind einstellbar.

Über das Spiel: 
Überragend war die damalige Möglichkeit des Spiels alle Gebäude frei bauen zu können wo man wollte, es gibt nur hinsichtlich vorhandener Hindernissen auf der Karte oder derem Rand eine kleine Einschränkung. Man kann also keine Gebäude auf den Kartenrand oder gar halb auf die Hindernisse setzten. Die Truppen die man Baut, lassen sich frei bewegen, alleine oder in Gruppen (die man wiederum frei zusammen stellen kann). Und auch wenn man nur von Oben auf das Spielfeld blickt, erkennt man dank der guten Darstellung und den damaligen 3D Effekten sehr gut die Unterschiede von den Gebäuden, Fahrzeugen, Hindernissen u.s.w.. Viele der Hindernisse geben hier die Möglichkeit (je nach Karte) den Gegner gezielt in eine Falle laufen zu lassen, da man auch Verteidigungsanlagen auf diese bauen kann. Klar ist auch, das der Gegner diese auch ausschalten kann, wenn er Sie erstmal ausgemacht hat. Von einfachen Aufklärungs- Fahrzeugen/Robotern bis hin zur EMP-Bombe ist alles dabei.

Zu guter Letzt:
Danke sagen möchte ich dem Steam Team, die dieses absolute Kult-Game mit in die Reihen aufgenommen haben. Sowie den Herrschaften die es ermöglicht haben mit Hilfe der Steam Plattform es auch auf neueren Systemen spielen zu können. Macht bitte weiter so und erhaltet und dieses Game auch für weiter Windows Versionen.

19879838.review:
Initially I thought this was a great game until I discovered one particular bu****** mechanic. Since WHEN does a building count as a unit? In pretty much every RTS ever made, a unit is MOBILE, a character or vehicle with combat, constructive, or special abilities. Buildings are STATIONARY. They typically do nothing to defend your base and are used for production purposes. So, let's say you're expanding your base, fighting tooth and claw for metal, building solar complexes and also building DEFENSES to PROTECT what you've had to fight hard for. Laser towers on resource spots, production buildings abroad so you can deploy forces from key locations. Well guess what? This whole time you've been expanding your base, you have been taking space from your COMBAT UNITS. 

There is a UNIT CAP. So now, if you do have an expanded base, there's a good chance the enemy has a larger fighting force than you and regardless of whether you attack or wait to be attacked, you'll take heavy casualties and the enemy will sense this and just overwhelm you with a larger army. Oh and the game DOESN'T tell you how close you're getting to the unit cap. So you basically have to finely tune the production of everything or else you might waste an hour and a half because your fighting units are crippled by the unit cap. This is the issue I've found in campaign and it's kind of horse s***.

In closing, why does a game called TOTAL ANNIHILATION, which is about the mass production of combat robots between two factions who have been hating each other for 400 years have this cap? It's like putting a diaper on a grizzly bear. Wherever we look, sentient robots are a HUGE problem. Terminator: the whole damn planet has been overrun with machines. Mass Effect: THE WHOLE F****** UNIVERSE is about to be destroyed by machines. Robots bring two things when they attack, firepower and numbers. In a game like Age of Empires it makes sense. Want to train more troops and villagers? You need more houses/castles for your people to shelter in. Robots don't give a f*** about rest and typically don't care about how much space is left on the planet, they just want to kill stuff!

19867126.review:
I'll warn it outright, this game review may have a bias of nearly 20 years of Nostalgia, but I still own my original disks and have for the most part, kept reinstalling up until those disks got scratched badly.

Back in 1997, this game blew my 9-year-old mind.  Yes the graphics are lack-luster compared to today, but we were running Windows 98 at the time.  This game is the first game of the Supreme Commander Series that, ironically takes place at the end of the war.

The music is astounding, you can just listen to the soundtrack and make a movie around them.  The classical style just makes the scene of hundreds of robots killing each other more epic.

Gameplay: It's an RTS.  Both sides are fairly equal, except the ARM units are faster where the CORE has more health...so picking a side really comes to looks.

You get the core game and all its expansion packs, which were great expansion packs for the game, from new units to the new campaign.

Also, the Aeon Illuminate don't exist, so that's a plus.


If you want a fit of nostalgia, get the game....if you want to see what us kids in the 90's played...get this game.

19867047.review:
An instant 10/10!

Gamers of this generation might or might not understand that THIS game is the CORE of RTS gaming.
The mechanics of the gameplay, the storyline, the tiers of the machines and the difference between the factions prove us that no corners were cut back in the day, and creators gave their best.

There is no explanation on how great is the feeling of a huge battlefield with constant explosions, shells, lasers, screenshakes and the amazing, AMAZING soundtrack by Jeremy Soul. To understand you just need to PLAY it.

This game was my whole childhood, then Supreme Commander appeared and i was disappointed since it lacked the same vibe, and had a lot of unnecessary features. Then, recently Planetary Annihilation came trying to give us that sense of nostalgia, but it still couldn't cut it for me. 
When i saw this game came on steam, this was an instant buy for me, and now, if we can transfer the whole modding community here on steam, and patch the game some more, it would have limitless potential.

What can i say, 
The games made today are awesome in their own way, really, but the old ones like Total Annihilation, Unreal and UT, AoE, or even Ubisoft's 2000's Infestation (a game that people barely remember existed which is very disappointing)
There is something special about them that today's games lack.

RTS Classic!  Works in Windows 10!  Tons of Missions!  Cheap!  Buy it!

Another favorite RTS from my childhood brought back to life!  Horraaayyy!  

Great strategy game with an interesting resource system, tons of units, tons of missions and hours of fun to be had!

Was ahead of its time in so many ways when it came out back in 1997 and it still has so much to offer, especially with the cheap price tag!  The expansions are also included so you get TONS of single player missions and content.  Only real drawbacks are the 1997 era graphics and occasional clumsy unit pathing.  

If you can look past the graphics, the depth and difficulty really do rival that of most modern RTS games.  There is also no Auto-Save type feature so make sure to save your game often!  (and also use your commander to capture the warp gates, don't blow them up!  You'll thank me later...) 

Despite being an old game it works great in Windows 10 with no compatibilty problems or issues.  Just install and go!

If you enjoy games like Command and Conquer, Warcraft 1 and 2, Starcraft, Supreme Commander, ect... Dont Skip this one!

Truely a classic and not to be missed!

If you are not sold on the orchestra and narrator, o god.. 
When i saw this 18 year old game come up on steam, im like. hey.. i still have the cd's in my desk. So i bought the game... again?

Man, i can't tell you how many thousands of hours i threw into this game while growing up, And the thousands more i have with the mods i downloaded.

Im running on a win10, i booted up the game and it worked flawlessly. had to google some things i forgot like adding -d for windows as a launch parameter, and setting the game's resolution in the main menu before starting the game. But after i got past the small things i jumped right into the game and started playing, killing some bots quickly and then moving on to some mods. 

2 mods to look at are zero, and escalation.

But without mods the game is considered a mass RTS. You start out with just your commander and you gather some metal deposits in the world, generate energy, and create some buildings for defenses, and factorys to produce your units. 
In a game like this, you want to be using up 100% of your produced resourses 24/7, pumping out as many units as you possibly can. If you go over, you run your storage dry and production gets slower. If you dont use 100% you end up wasting excess when your storage is full. 

Default maps are very bland for me, i usually just to randomly pick one and go with it. 
And if you play against the AI, even on the hardest difficulty you are going to destroy them easily in a 1v1, once you know the base of the game.

19832995.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
One of the seminal 3D games of the RTS genre, this game was far ahead of its time when released. Total Annihilation still remains peerless in how well rounded it is, from both sequels and rivals.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
The simplicity of the mechanics is the game's strongest point. All aspects of the game are easy to understand and intuitive. From a clean UI, to satisfying movement and speed of vehicles, the game just feels right. Once you've completed the campaign, skirmishes will entertain for a long time.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The visuals still hold up, with solidly modeled machines, angling to accommodate the contours of the landscape - an original feature at release, it still looks convincing to this day. A very complete selection of environment types to choose from, offering varied experiences.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The music of the game is excellent. Sometimes pensively tense, at other times sorrowful, and occasionally stirring with strident pride - but always memorable.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Perhaps one of the most wholesome RTS games of all time, and certainly one of the most technologically innovative of its time. Own a piece of PC gaming history.

Oh man, this game. This. Game.  From a CD-R of the skirmish disc to a legit big box copy, I invested hundreds if not thousands of hours in [i]Total Annihilation[/i] during the tail-end of the 90s. Its relaxed pace, expansive map size and tactical variety put the microscopic, tunnel-visioned zerg rush of [i]StarCraft[/i] and [i]Red Alert[/i] to shame, the competitor's popularity be damned.

My opinion has not changed in the nearly two decades that have passed since [i]Total Annihilation's[/i] launch date; this is still a forward-thinking masterwork of the RTS genre, its eerily desolate atmosphere and lush, Jeremy Soule-composed score just as evocative as it was back then.

Am I biased? Perhaps. Is it perfect? Not at all, but given the time period and meager price tag for what is the definitive [i]Total Annihilation[/i] experience? More than worth a revisiting for newcomers and veterans alike.

단점이라면 병맛 스토리, 단조로운 미션, 그리고 멀티플레이를 어떻게 하느냐 정도겠네요. 정 멀티를 하려면 ip주소 입력해서 해야 될 듯합니다. 하긴 이 게임은 싱글도 충분히 어려우니 스커미쉬나 크로고스 인카운터같은 극한 미션까지 도전하는 걸로도 돈값은 하겠네요.

결론은... 지르세요. 스타벅스 카페라떼 벤티 사이즈 한 번 안먹는다고 생각하는 겁니다. 이게 한 만원 이랬으면 좀 망설였을 텐데 5500원이네요? 그러면 일단 사고 보는겁니다.

19819233.review:
Loved TA back in the day and was very happy to see it land on Steam. It is one of my all time favorites.

The only downside is that there is a glitch when running the game from Steam for the first time. For me it was an easy fix (as described below).

If you're ok with doing a one-time workaround, then definitely go purchase this game. Otherwise, I’d wait a little while. The game was recently released and I’m sure it will be fixed fairly soon.

So here’s the problem and my fix. Keep in mind that this worked for me and may not work for everyone!

Problem: 
When launching TA for the first time through Steam, I kept getting “Error: Environment initialization failed! Check your DirectX”

The Fix:
Launched the game directly by running TotalA.exe. This is found in the installation folder:
C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Total Annihilation

Afterwards, you should be able to start TA from Steam everytime.


If the above does not work, then take a look at Peepswood's post describing how to use these patches:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/298030/discussions/0/487877107150113391/


If this issue is officialy resolved, then I will change my review to a thumbs up

19819218.review:
Нестареющая классика. 
На 1997 год Total Annihilation безусловный графический прорыв и гигантский рывок вперед, сравнимый с Quake и Crysis у шутеров. В 1997 году у Total Annihilation уже были: 3д-модели, осязаемые карты высот, обсчет физики каждого юнита, горящий лес, динамические тени и при этом сотни юнитов на экране на гигантских картах. Всё это без тормозов на pentium 133 с 32 mb ram. Гениальный движок, даже сейчас в 4K игра смотрится потрсящающе.  
А сетевой код был запилен так удачно, что TA до сих пор играбельна онлайн и, мне кажется, ведет себя даже постабильнее своего последователя Supreme Commander.

Всё бы это было пустыми словами, если бы в саму игру не была вложена душа. Геймплей, если кратко - потрясающий.  TA ни в коем случае нельзя назвать клоном CnC, как пытались клеймить её  в 90-ых. Бесконечная штамповка роботов с десятков заводов, груды дымящегося металла на полях битв, который тут же собирают экономные машины-конверторы, универсальный командир с ультрапушкой d-gun и способный передвигаться даже по океаническому дну, уникальные технические уровни у зданий. Гигантские боевые машины - Кроготы, рядом с которыми все остальные кажутся просто блохами.

  И третье, на моей памяти первая игра с такой поддержкой модов, сами разработчики способствовали моддерам и тем самым обессмертили игру. Total Annihilation уже 18 лет, а патчи от фанатов до сих пор выходят. В последнем добавили mega-map - аналог полноэкранной карты из Supreme Commander'а, которая вызывается колёсиком мыши. Появилась возможность просмотра реплеев сыгранных игр, как в каком-нибудь Старкрафт.  Да что там, по игре до сих пор проводятся турниры с денежными призами. 
Ну и тысячи карт сделанных фанатами, тысячи моделей юнитов, сотни модов. 

Касаемо стимовской версии: запустилась на windows 10, fullhd, alt-tab работает, музыка и звук есть, включены все два официальных аддона.

Вывод: игра действительно сильно опередила время и завоевала сердца игроков. Тут и речи быть не может о другой оценке: 10/10.

19818716.review:
I'm a pretty crappy writer so I apologize in advance.

Total Annihilation is an incredibly unique and intense RTS that was light-years ahead of its time and still is today. I still strongly prefer the original over the more spiritual-successor, Planetary Annihilation.

Total Annihilation features so many small features that just make it amazing, the battles can be huge and intense with massive amounts of units having a huge Warhammer 40k esque fight all on one screen, or the games can be slow and brilliantly thought out. This is a strategy game where you can win purely by 'defensive' play at times, something I find to be rather unique among a lot of strategy games that even today have rather narrow methods to win, usually by just having the larger and better offensive force, but not always in Total Annihilation. 

A feature that makes Total Annihilation so unique is the true emphasis on a defensive playstyle, if you so desire. There are an impressive amount of options for defensive, slow play styles and faster, more offensive playstyles alike. You can choose to hunker down and improve your economy while building a large amount of turrets and upgrading to better ones over the course of the game, some are even capable of bombarding your opponent from the entire maps length, assuming you reach the demanding level of tech and economy required for them. Even tactical nukes can be constructed and launched over a map away if the game length and level of sustainable economy is reached. This allows for a lot of options for a lot of different types of players. There is also no real super demanding macro-memory required à la StarCraft II, making the game just a bit more accessable to newer players, especially in more team oriented game modes.

The game also features incredible physics for it's more 2.5 dimensional, isometric strategy experience. One of my favourite things about this game is seeing things like unit inaccuracy, especially when on the move or on unstable ground or even when taking pot-shots at something through the fog-of-war. Units will have better vision when on the high ground and worse vision when in a trench, making a lot of areas on maps incredibly strategic locations. There's even bullet physics, units will often adjust their aim higher or lower depending on the target, and when the steel corpses begin to litter the battlefield they will often block incoming rounds harmlessly while your units continue to trudge past the enemy fire. There's a gritty feeling seeing all your units charge an enemy fortified position only to begin seeing the missiles and rounds begin to rain down upon them and seeing a huge chunk of your force get obliterated by a large round, shaking the screen and sending chunks of steel flying in every direction, the steel "gibs" even damaging nearby units who get hit by them.

The game also features an amazing orchestral 'dynamic' music score written and composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule. The music really compliments an already fantastic game nicely, changing to a more brooding tone as you build up your base and switching to a more heart-pounding score as enemy fighters engage your army. It's an incredible soundtrack that you may even consider finding for your own music player. The sound design alone in this game is also very unique and give it a great distinct and 'mechanical' feel.

If there was one strategy that I think is criminally unknown to most people, this would have to be it. It's made an amazingly tight-knit community that continue to play the original and have a huge modding scene. (Seriously, try the Total Annihilation Escalation mod, it's just insanely good.) Some even going as far as recreating the Total Annihilation experience in full 3D via an open source engine called Spring, try Spring Total Annihilation out sometime, it has a great community still supporting it to this day.

Overall it's my favourite RTS game of all time, and I'm not even a huge RTS fan. It's incredibly exciting just to watch with an amazing soundtrack and huge, epic battles.

10/10, would D-Gun again.

19813343.review:
This is one of those old games that age really really well. like the GOG version it works fine on newer systems. And no need for mods to get 1080p or higher. As the game even back in 1997 did scale to your max windows resolutions, sadly the game UI don't. Nor the radar. So at 2K or 4K they are really tiny. And ofc this has the addon "The Core Contingency" and lots of other old bonus missions. And yes. I use Win10 and it works just fine. At the time of this writing the Arm campaing is done, 11 hours played and not a single crash.. 

This game is equally great for turtle players and rushers alike. The SP campaign AI can be brutal on the attacks at times. But even a turtle player can focus on defenses and hold up until he is ready. Some of the maps are huge and will need some micro managing to get around well, but take your time and it will work out. There are tons of units to select from. So it will fit any style you have the more you progress in the story. I would recommend to google keyboard shortcuts, as there are a ton of then to make the game easier to handle. As the game set the standard for way point systems, so you can order a unit to move to the enemy base, attack a unit, fall back and patrol the base all in one way point go. Or set the commander to build a few buildings while you attack or scout.


For this price, even not on a discount. You would be foolish to skip this part of RTS history. It set the standards along with C&C for all time to come. Old or new RTS player, it won't take long to get into this gem. Even with the huge unit count. Only downside is that buildings count towards the unit cap at 200. But each unit counts as 1. Not 1 to 8 like in SC.

Highly recommended.

It felt like christmas come early today when I saw this game finally come to Steam. This game was my childhood. Any fan of RTS really needs to have played this! 19808384.review:
Total Annihilation is the defining game of the RTS genre. Looking back to the late 90s and the technology available then, this game was amazingly advanced and did many things that weren't at all common then. Many common RTS elements that are expected in a game released today can be seen in their youth in TA. The order queuing system, the streaming resource and building systems, the diversity of units and asymmetrical factions are all key features that were later used in practically every RTS since. You can clearly see the foundation of Supreme Commander especially. There are aspects of TA that still haven’t been matched, such as the unit diversity: Air, Land, Sea, Seaplane, Hovercraft, Amphibious.

Like artillery? How about the Intimidator, which can fire halfway across the map? Too slow? Build the Buzzsaw: a giant rotary cannon made up of Intimidators that fires as fast as a machine gun and will drain your energy economy in seconds. Yes, it IS the most entertaining gun ever!

The music of TA is the best orchestral soundtrack ever made for a game. I still sometimes listen to the "battle" tracks in my car. I turn the music off in every other game I’ve played and listen to “real” music instead (I remember listening to Spice Girls on a CD while playing), but TA got to keep its soundtrack.

I think a large part of what made TA such a fun and long lasting experience was the modding community. I remember spending as much time finding, downloading (V.90 modem, yo), and figuring out conflicts between mods as playing the game, but those mods extended the diversity and playability of the game so extensively that there are still active players AND active modders for TA. You don’t see that with too many 19 year-old games.

The chief contender for the RTS throne was Starcraft, which was released right around the same time as TA, and went on to define the "twitch" RTS subgenre. Coming from Warcraft 2, I remember buying both games, and being rather disappointed in Starcraft, since it seemed to me to be "Warcraft in space". TA was something entirely new and captured that certain something that makes it a gaming classic... and I've probably spent more time in this game than any other, ever.

19800880.review:
TLDR; This is the game that inspired tons of RTS games as well as people. BUYITRIGHTNOWGO

I write this review holding my original copy of Total Annihilation in hand. But I'll just set it down, so I can type better. This game is what many other games have tried to emulate, but have failed in some aspect (looking mainly at YOU, Planetary Annihilation). It really should be able to please just about any RTS fan. Want a quick, in your face battle? You got it. Want a long war of attrition? Done (Play Seven Islands for an epic air/sea/nuke battle royale). The campaign is pretty solid too, from what I remember. 

The music is what I remembered the most, I think. It was just so epic, and fit the game so perfectly. And, for a game that's pushing 20 years old, it still has a charming look to it, not too far off from some indie games released much later. Sometimes pathing can be a bit annoying, but when your units get stuck, just blast them with your Commander's D-gun, for instant gratification.

I think really the only negative thing I can say, is that this version includes all the expansion(s). I felt the base game is awesome without the new units and such. Also, I can't help but notice that the AI had to have been tweaked in some ways. It's much more predictable with the xpacs, and dumbed down. It is nice they included the map editor though, sometimes it feels that the provided maps can get stale. That might also be from playing every map many, many times.

Cavedog was a pretty legit developer that just unfortunately got overwhelmed by a small market at that time period. I loved their other release, TA: Kingdoms as well. I've sunk tons and tons of hours into both TA series. And Boneyards (their inhouse online service) was so ahead of its time, as far as matchmaking, community, patch releases, and content updates on the reg, it's a shame nothing else has really come along, at least for me, that made the same impression.

Pro Tip(s): You want more than 4 players/AI in a skirmish? After hitting the 'single' button, press * and the corresponding roman numeral to the amount of players you want. Example: *X would bump the limit to 10. Reap benefits and/or get rekt.

You want to play any campaign mission, any way? From the main menu, click 'Single' then type, drdeath    All one word, no spaces, lowercase. A bone will appear in the gap on the right menu, that once clicked, a campaign master menu opens up, from which you can select any assortment of mission you'd like.

19796334.review:
Certainly not a perfect version. It still has issues of disappearing status bar at the bottom of the screen if you actually run AT your resolution (1920x1080 for example), you gotta run at something like 1680x900 in order to actually see the entire UI on screen, which is ridiculous.
And it really is a must, because you NEED that status bar to see build rates, energy and metal rates, etc for selected or hovered-over items and factories.

The great thing however is that this IS the best working version so far. You dont have to edit .ini files or use third party apps to get it running properly in fullscreen without glitches, apart from the above mentioned. For that alone it is worth a rebuy (because we cant really blame the original devs for not considering Windows 8 / 10 compatability, now can we?) :)

That said, I highly recommend people to immediately get some of the convenience mods / balance patches out there.
In some ways they are almost required to enjoy the game in a modern RTS mindset.
Such as being able to select groups with just pressing 1, instead of pressing Alt+1 which was ridiculous at that time, and is still highly user-unfriendly today.
Or being able to hold and drag buildings when holding shift. Makes building walls feasible, which it wasnt in vanilla TA placing one at a time, click click click click.

A great masterpiece of a game that DOES show its age due to some weird control schemes they opted for in the old days.
But with mods to modernize and "logicalize" the controls, it still holds up today, despite the awful pathfinding.
The pure atmosphere and "feel" of the game is still un-rivaled. No other RTS "feels" like TA.
Perhaps it is the music, perhaps it is the graphics, perhaps it is the clunky slow controls.
No matter what it is, it is greater than the sum of its part. A robbery at this price, must-buy.

19787106.review:
One of the best games of my high school years. I have played this game so much, I don't think any other game can compare. The modding community at the time was crazy, tons of new options to add in. You can still find mods to this day. The first one was great but the expansions added so much more to the game. For its time this game was the Farcry of RTS, graphics were amazing, maps were never ending, and battles were not capped to 200 units per player. Game defaults to 1000 units, however patchs are available, or a simple edit of the config file to allow as many as you desire.

When cavedog first offered their gaming service to connect players it was all I ever did. I finally had an endless amount of players to play with. It is just sad that the sequal to the game was such a downfall in the game play department. Seems to collopsed their mightly RTS empire.

I hope you all enjoy this game as much as I did. 

Just some helpful hints to play the game, starting with before you actually play
 It doesn't appear narration is available in the game, sad face. Maybe it is just mine. Secondly change left click to right click in the menus if your used to other RTS. Game sound starts at mono and can be changes to 3D (Stereo). Options accessed only once you select single or multiple player. Options in game can be selected by pressing tab. Game I believe is auto paused on start for all maps. Resolution support works for 1080p but must be selected, most games at this time barely supported 1280x1028.
 
 While playing:
 Speed can be adjusted during single and multiple player via the + or - buttons. 
 Multiple buildings can be queued together using shift.
 Resource sharing is possible with allies at set increments so you never have to constantly send resources.
 Building units also has an infinite queue. Holding shift increments 5. Left click to add units, right click to remove.
 Your commander has a gun called the D-Gun hot key is D, this is a huge blast that can one shot everything but a commander and expieremental units not in the original (later expansions).
 If your commander dies in campaign it is the end of the match, multiplayer depending on settings. Your commander blows up like a big nuke.
 Planes build the slowest, then Kbots, then vechicles. Forgot hover vechicles, but they are in an expansion as well. Each one has different perks, and should be used together to cordinate strikes. However planes usually over power all else, as they are fast, hard to hit, and cheap to build.

19783947.review:
Funny how the world works sometimes. I remember walking through Sam's Club back in 1997 and seeing the display for this game. A buddy of mine bought the game and told me you gotta see this game. Never before had we seen anything like it and we were instantly hooked as were several other of our friends. Back the, you had to download a program so you play against others, so we opted for Lan parties instead.
Since 1997, I have pulled this game out and played it everyyear since. When I tried to load it up a week ago, it didn't work. Was a little dissappointed and thought it was time to move on and then it popped up on my front page yesterday. I didn't hesitate.
The base game and both expansions are here and there are at least 150 single player missions and more units than you can possibly imagine. Makes for very large scale battles, especially if you are playing on one of the metal maps. The graphics are obviousley lacking and the game isn't as revelutionary as it was then, but this game has great meaning for me and changed the way I viewed gaming. It was the first game that got me really excited and it changed the way games were made.
I remember Chris Taylor saying he wanted to go straight to TA2, but they wanted to make TA:Kingdoms, which was a game I enjoyed, but not even close to as much as TA. And because they didn't go straight to TA2, well, the rest is history. TA:K didn't do so well and the company eventually went under with no sequel ever done. The ownership has changed many times over (last I heard a company in Japan had it and wouldn't part with it) and a sequel does not seem to ever be coming which is a tragedy. It is probably one of the reasons this game is as iconic and beloved as it still is today.
After loading up the game last night, I coudn't beleive that 2 hours had passed so quickly. Still love and cherish this game.

Still loving this game and just played it for the 20th year in a row.

Still waiting after all these years for a sequel. Do I think we will get one: Nope. Game still excites me after all these years.

19782202.review:
I haven't seen this game in years! Just reading about it brough so much nostalgia - I still have 2 CDs for the game, with the booklet on story and individual units in my home country somewhere. I played it when I was little, when I couldn't understand a word in English XD
One disk was for Single and the other for Multi player after installation, I believe.

The game itself was brilliant, so versatile and with so many options and units, advanced extraction facilities and units - and that was just the original version - never had the expansions before.
Unique system of having one special unit called Commander, who you used to build basic structures and then had to protect him from destruction, or you would loose. You can capture buildings and enemies with him, and if you did it correctly, you could then start building units and buildings of the opposite fracion! Not that it would matter much though, as both fractions have almost idenical units for most part (varied just look and attack type), even the same number of them varies just by 2-4 objects less or more on each side ovarall.

Going in Skirmish mode against AI was a bit pointless though - Difficulty gave the AI upper hand, instead of making it smarter. The enemy almost never used advanced weaponry, or buildings. I hope this will be different with this version.

Despite its little flaws above, it could still be called [b]indescribably brilliant game[/b] - at the time of its relevance, and even in this day. Give me Total Annihilation over some of those new fancy RTSs any time.

19781689.review:
Don't mistake Steam playing time here:

I was 10 when this came out, playing on our old Amstrad Pentium 100MhZ with 1gb HDD. By 1997 we could only really have one game on the PC to play, and Total Annihilation spent alot of time on there. Coming from C&C and AoE TA just blew them out of the water, two lovingly crafted factions, totally unique units and such a wide array of units it had too! You were never locked down into a play style, you had the tools to do whatever you felt necessary. Maps were varied, from closed corridor battles to open ground which often changed from pristine wildernesses to a decimated hell hole throughout the course of the map.

The amount of content here is vast, it's an old school campaign, so tons of missions with good scaling difficulty, piles of maps for skirmishing and top mods available. Not to mention a top soundtrack by Jeremy Soule (Elder Scrolls, KOTOR etc).

And for the pittance they're asking, this a steal.

19780307.review:
Quand j'étais gamine, il y avait 4 séries de STR qui m'avaient marqué, plus que les autres :

Les Earth 21XX (on enlèvera le 2160 de la liste :p ), les Battlezone (str en vue FPS), Warzone 2100 et les 2 Total Annihilation : celui-ci et sa version fantasy sortie plus tard, Total Annihilation Kingdoms. (Autant dire que comme Steam commence à les ressortir, j'ai tendance à les attraper méchamment au vol^^)

Ce jeu  a vieilli, mais il y a ce "on ne sait quoi" que je ne retrouve plus dans les STR modernes, et qui était très présent dans toutes ces franchises, et plus dans ce jeu là en particulier. cette peur de perdre sa base suite à un missile nucléaire bien placé, avant qu'on ait eu le temps de construire l'anti-missile, cette peur (ou cet amour selon^^) pour la Grosse Bertha... et j'en passe^^ Cette obligation de rigueur et de concentration sur de longues périodes aussi.

Et puis c'était une ambiance aussi! A l'époque, on avait pas la capacité de faire de grands orchestres musicaux, alors pour sortir du lot, il fallait s'arracher niveau ambiance. Ces sons sont si reconnaissables!

Pas de miro-placements, mais une gestion des unités manuelles tout de même très présente et aboutie, une évolution des bâtiments / ressources / technos à gérer de manière très rigoureuse. Il n'était pas facile ce jeu, mais il était et il est toujours prenant!

Ce n'est pas le plus vieux des STR qui ait été lancé, mais c'est le plus vieux auquel j'ai joué, et toutes les mécaniques sont déjà bien présentes!

A tous les fans de STR je le conseille. De mon point de vue, c"est un standard :P on ne peut pas jouer aux STR et ne pas connaître ce magnifique vétéran du genre ^_^ D'autant qu'on lui doit la plupart du gameplay des STR modernes!

Ah j'oubliais : ce n'est pas dit, mais l'extention m'a l'air incluse, contrairement à ce que dit la description Oo

Pas de multi par contre, mais une bonne prise en charge de l'éditeur de map, et donc des mods^^

19775048.review:
Easily one of the best RTS games of all time while also being the predecessor to Supreme Commander and Planetary Annihilation. Hoping to see this game worked on the same way Age of Empires II HD is being developed by eliminating bugs, Steam Workshop integration, improving multiplayer stability and implementing a lobby system.

Gameplay Features:

  + Many unit types - Bots, Vehicles, Airplanes, Ships, Subs and Hovercrafts.
  + Numerous tilesets with some offering unique experiences such as Water, Acid and Metal worlds.
  + Maps have their own gravity, wind and tidal strength affecting certain resource generating structures and weapons.
  + Resources are infinite with several ways to generate them, they're only limited by your economy.
  
This version:

  + Includes Core Contingency, Battle Tactics and v3.1, the last official patch.
  + Runs well on newer OS
  + Includes the map editor
  + Heavily and easily moddable just like every other version.

  - Game seems to crash when trying to load a saved game.
  - Multiplayer wasn't updated

Although not the same game, I have precious memories of playing TA on the Spring Engine and having large-scale battles. I hope I'm able to do the same through this game one day.

19773912.review: It looks like just a bunch of robots killing each other to most people, but Total Annihilation is one of the deepest darkest stories ever told. It's the only accurate game I've ever seen about our future, where humans are all dead and the arm clones fight the core planetary mind for control of the universe.  They don't even care about being alive or anything, they just want to annihilate the other side so so much.  Sometimes a battle can take like 8 hours and just grind on, it takes so much willpower to keep going, or to even notice when you get nuked.  It's an endless battle.  It also has a great soundtrack written by Jeremy Seole, who wrote a lot of the music in Secret of Evermore.  The first time I saw Total Annihilation, I was in Circuit City and I saw this cool looking guy getting bombed by 50 fast moving fighters and planes and he couldn't stop the computer from killing him and he eventually lost his commander and then his last towers and the map went grey.  It was like 1997 or something and he must have been horrible at the game and I don't think either of us bought anything from circuit city that day, but to see that cool guy get annihilated by an endless wave of planes was shocking to me.  He said "damn it" or something like that and then looked at his watch and said "oh no" and then he ran away, I guess he had to go somewhere and was late.  I saw it as a great challenge to become as good as he was some day, and I still feel like I'm not, but objectively I must have met that challenge because I have won wars against 10 computer players with population limits in the thousands.  If I could go back in time, I would go back there, ask him if i could help, and save his base.

19771096.review:
One of the best RTS ever made. The scale of those battles was so much bigger than anything else at that time, I had a hard time playing any other RTS for years after TA.

The classical music, played by 96-piece Northwest Sinfonia orchestra, was also perfectly fitting for that kind of game, really good quality by Jeremy Soule, composer of Icewind Dale, Baldur's gate, Oblivion, Skyrim music and many more. Music switched depending on what you were doing, which was also uncommon at that time (with "battle themes" and "quiet themes" for construction phases, something we didn't see in every game at that time).

Unit animation was also awesome for that time, with all those small robots animated everywhere. Seeing a group of robots run in one direction but with their torsos turned in another to shoot at an enemy is fun to see.

The game universe is great, very varied, lots of different map styles and landscapes. Game depth can be quite deep. There is A LOT of units (hundreds in base game, and hundreds in each DLC), and quite a lot of them are useful. Also has an incredible mix of units, from "pure" land tanks, or bombers, to planes that can "land" underwater, amphibious tanks, hovercraft units. Same for resources, a lot of different ways to get any of each of them, for power for example, you can go solar, nuclear, hydro plants, wind plants, etc.

Also, low price, all extensions (DLC) included, much better than all those 20 years old base games with terrible port sold for over $10.

19768782.review:
Das RTS Spiel was mich Jahrelang gefesselt hat. 

Ich Spiele es schon ewige Zeiten und heute noch gern im Multiplayer. 

Die Fraktionen sind ausgeglichen, unterscheiden sich jedoch nicht grundlegend. Arm hat z.B. leichter gepanzerte Einheiten, die auch weniger Kosten, wohin gegen Core stärker gepanzerte Einheiten mit höheren Kosten hat (gilt jedoch nicht für alle Einheiten). Die Einheiten Leveln nach abschüssen, wenn auch sie nur zum Veteran werden können. Das gibt der Einheit dann einen kleinen Bonus auf Zielsicherheit, macht sie aber nicht übermäßig stark wie in andern RTS-Titeln, wo das Leveln der Einheiten schon an RPG Spiele erinnert.

Die Kampagne beider Seiten sind gut und führen einen an die Einheiten herran. Im Skirmish (Gefecht) sollte man jedoch nicht allzuviel vom Computer erwarten (Er nutzt z.B. keine Atomraketen, woher man selbst auch keine nutzen sollte).

Im Multiplayer geht der Spass erst los. Hier reicht es nicht einfach die stärkste Einheit zu bauen und auf den Gegner zu Jagen. Selbst mit den billigesten Einheiten kann man im fortgeschrittenen Spiel noch Siegen (Masse statt Klasse). Egal See, Land oder Luftschlacht, jede Einheit kann nützlich sein, wenn man rausfindet wie man sie nutzen kann.

Die Grafik ist zwar mittlerweile altbacken, war jedoch für damalige Verhältnisse sehr gut und hat mit echten 3D Einheiten aufgewartet. Das Gelände ist Zweidimensional, hat jedoch verschiedene Höhenlinien. Diese verbessern unter anderem auch die Reichweite von Waffen, die sich auf hohen Orten befinden. Oder man nutzt die Geländeformationen als natürlichen Schutz vor eben jenen Waffen. Einheiten bewegen sich Bergauf langsamer als Bergab.

Die Modder-Community im Internet ist bis heute Aktiv und bringt Patchs und Mods herraus. Diese haben teilweise nur Einheiten hinzugefügt oder andere das Spiel komplett umgeschrieben um z.B. C&C nachzubilden oder eigenen Spiele zu erstellen.

Man sollte den 5000-Einheiten patch (5k-Unit-patch) nachinstallieren. Auch wenn man seltenst diese Einheitenanzahl benötigen wird, so macht es wesentlich mehr Spass die möglichkeit zu haben und mit Ein- bis Zweitausend Einheiten gegen den Gegener zu werfen. Und noch mehr wenn man merkt, dass es gerade genug waren!

Ich kann das Spiel nur empfehlen.

19768025.review:
Total Annihilation, the legend.
I remember playing this game nearly every day after school. I fired it up again now, and it's just as awesome as I remember. Many more hours will follow. 
TA pioneered so many great concepts and there are still RTS games that try and fail at being as good a game as this is. It's well balanced, it's exciting and the soundtrack is unlike anything you get these days, I still remember hearing my CD-ROM drive winding up as I was being attacked, trying to change songs to something more upbeat. 
It's addictive too, with memorable and unique units across the board (especially the planes that are properly fast). Also, 1920 x 1080 in 1997. 
This is the game that stood the test of time, and it continues to do so with every passing year.
I could go on but all I can say is: Worth every cent.

19767381.review: One of the best rts games!

19767282.review:
This game is quite possibly the single greatest video game ever made. When it was released in 1997, Total Annihilation was so far ahead of its time that in some respects it has never been duplicated since.

At the time I write this review there is no Steamworks multiplayer or Workshop mod support. But if these things are implemented, I have no doubts whatsoever that we will see a huge resurgence of Total Annihilation. There are already tens of thousands of third-party units, many mega-mods of hundreds of units, total conversions for everything from Star Wars to WWII to Gundam, to entirely new games built on TA as a basis. The amount of strategic depth flowing from fairly simple rules of collecting metal from metal spots and using it to construct various types of units, using a continous economy, physics-based battles, and a serious need for planning and tactics rather than unit counter relationships, make Total Annihilation a much deeper and more interesting strategy game than most of its contemporary cousins, including Starcraft and Age of Empires.

Real time strategy games have been starved for ideas for many years now, with the most successful ones being sequels and spiritual successors to genuinely innovative strategy games from the '90s. Alongside Starcraft, Total Annihilation is one of the great progenitors of the modern era of strategy games, and in many respects it has never been equaled.

19760452.review:
Word of Warning it is a nostalgic game.

A true RTS Game that could be said to have out lasted Starcraft Brood War and inspired the next generation of Real Time Stratergy games, Remember fondly playing this game as a kid and back in the day it was perhaps one of the first community driven games that boasted thousands of mods and total conversions from Star Wars to the Modern World this game was much like the Skyrim of the 90's with an seemingly endless supply of units, mods, and creativity on the part of the community.

Unsurprisingly this hasn't changed, Total Annihilation still retains a small but solid community of players ranging from Casuals to Professionals all it covers all the basis for a RTS game but not without it's issues.

The base game is known to suffer from pathfinding issues, you'll frequently find that without the use of mods or modified scripts the AI will struggle considerably and will at times do stupid things that might ruin the experiance of players looking for a challenge, if that's you then I'd recommend either playing with friends or joining one of the many communities out their!

Or look into getting one of the many mods the game supports, most if not all improve the AI come to ruthless degrees where you'll hard pressed to both micro and marco manage an entire force of soulless machines. The best way I can descrbe it would be to think of Skyrim without mods, then think of Skyrim with mods that's effectively TA in a nuthshell.

Options:

+ The developers certainly had longevity in mind, you can adjust the resolution up to 1920 x 1080.
+ Provides all the options you might expect from a game of this age, perhaps abit more.
- On/Off only, you can't find a middle ground without adjusting the files directly.

Gameplay

+ A map for everybody! - every map has something for everybody the metal maps provide infinite resources and lead to a fast-paced style game. In contrast low metal maps have you fighting over resources while slowly pushing your way into the enemy base. Maps on distant moons have you transporting units by air over impassable chasms or bombing your opponent into the dust.

+ Play how you want - Many RTS games have a 'defined' stratergy TA has no such definition, you will encounter players who love the good old peepee rush or those whose sole purpose is to watch you squirm as they destroy your outlying extractors. You'll encounter the turtles naturally but the game provides you with all the nessesary tools to enact your stratergy and descimate others.

- AI Pathfinding - As mentioned the pathfinding is horrible and will almost certainly require fixing especially if you want to play Skirmish thankfully their are mods and simple scripts to fix this.

- Performance - Most modern day PC's won't have a problem until like Skyrim you hit a point where your computer begins to chug along. This tends to arise from heavily modded games especially when you start to up the unit cap from 200 to 1000+

Community:

+ Still going strong not much else to say here besides the fact you have over 10 years of mods to discover some of which have been developed over so many years.
